Dehkordi Supervision Writing - review & editing b a McGill University, Montreal, Quebec, Canada McGill University Montreal Quebec Canada McGill University, Montreal, Quebec, Canada b NRCan-CanmetENERGY, Varennes, Quebec, Canada NRCan-CanmetENERGY Varennes Quebec Canada NRCan-CanmetENERGY, Varennes, Quebec, Canada ∗ Corresponding author. A novel implementation strategy of a centralized model predictive control (MPC) is proposed for a zone based comfort and energy management in a residential building. A photovoltaic (PV) solar system and a stationary home battery unit are considered. A heat pump (HP) is used as the primary heating unit. The electric baseboards (BB) are used as a supplementary system. The MPC controls the HP and BB power inputs for comfort management, as well as the energy flow among the PV, the battery and the bidirectional grid system. Variable Time-of-Use (ToU) rates are considered for the energy cost calculation and Feed-in-Tariff (FiT) is considered for selling energy to the grid. A 13.5% reduction in the energy cost is achieved with the centralized MPC as compared to a rule based energy management strategy. The solar energy generation and battery storage contribute to approximately 31% saving. Introduction The heating system is an integral part of the heating, ventilation and air-conditioning (HVAC) system that constitutes the major part of the residential electrical load. But the non-thermal electrical loads, such as, daily hot water requirement, electrical appliances, lighting, also add to the net residential electricity consumption. In this article, an inclusive control strategy for overall energy and comfort management of a residential building is presented considering renewable energy generation and storage. The benefits of a grid connected PV generation system coupled with a battery storage unit is studied in Ref. [13] based on different electricity rates, feed-in tariff (FiT) incentive and battery storage unit cost. In Ref. [5], a finite-horizon MPC control is used as a building energy management controller for optimal scheduling of thermostatically controlled heating-cooling units. For the non-thermal units, the MPC minimizes the electricity expense by controlling the ON/OFF status of the appliances and thereby optimizing the delay between the occupants’ requests of using an appliance and its availability, based on variable electricity rates. For the thermal appliance scheduling, predicted mean vote (PMV) index is used as an indicator of occupants’ comfort. The allowable PMV range in Ref. [5] is used as an optimization constraint. A similar PMV index based comfort constraint is used in MPC building energy cost optimization in Ref. [25]. Another MPC based strategy for hygrothermal comfort and energy management in an office building is presented in Ref. [9]. The objective function includes penalties on operative temperature and humidity setpoint deviations along with energy cost. In Ref. [3] the MPC objective function uses a penalty on the comfort optimization based on a flexible comfort range defined by slack variables corresponding to acceptable temperature bounds. However, no energy cost penalty is considered. While focusing on a similar objective of achieving desired comfort at a reduced energy cost, the goal of this paper is to introduce a single centralized MPC that not only maintains the indoor operative temperature within a given range, but also simultaneously optimizes the timing and amount of energy flow during the charging-discharging of the home battery, the utilization of the renewable and/or grid based energy to reduce the energy cost. Unlike the comfort optimization constraint presented in Ref. [5,25], the choice of an hourly variable schedule of an allowable temperature range, gives the MPC the necessary flexibility in achieving a trade off between the heating power inputs and the total electrical energy cost for the thermal and non-thermal appliances used in the house. In several earlier studies the performance benefits of an MPC over a classical rule based ON/OFF controller and PID controllers have been presented [1]. In this article, the contribution is focused on the performance of the MPC in an amalgamated comfort and energy management optimization scenario, hence the base case presented in this study has an MPC driven comfort and energy cost optimization with a rule based control for the energy management. In the following, the objective is presented in Section 2. A description of the case study house and its heating systems and energy network arrangements are given in Section 3, where in Section 4 the control-oriented house model is presented. The disturbance inputs used in this simulation study and the optimization problem formulation are presented in Section 5 and Section 6, respectively. Two case study scenarios are described in Section 7 and the optimization results are presented in Section 8. Finally, Section 9 summarizes the work presented in this article. 2 Objectives The building energy management system (BEMS) presented in this article includes an on-site solar energy generation system and a battery storage facility. A bidirectional grid connection is considered. The BEMS is centrally controlled by the MPC which performs a multi-variable optimization, with a single objective function, to efficiently manage the renewable energy usage, charging and discharging of the battery and heating load distribution to maintain the indoor operative temperature within given comfort bounds with a reduced heating energy consumption. The proposed approach contributes in combining two major building control engineering research focuses, namely the HVAC control for comfort management with low operative cost and energy management for building electricity consumption. A TRNSYS-MATLAB co-simulation is used for this comfort and energy management case studies. Here, the TRNSYS house is treated as an alternative to the actual physical house. The MPC, coded in MATLAB, uses a simplified linear model of the TRNSYS house for temperature predictions and control. A similar co-simulation arrangement is described in detail in Refs. [26,27]. 3 The case study house The layout of the single-storey house is created using Google SketchUp and TRNSYS. This TRNSYS model is used as an alternative to the real physical building [26,27]. The house has two bedrooms and a living-dining space with an open kitchen. The construction specifications are presented in Table 1 . The PV panels are installed on a South facing roof inclined at an angle of 45 ° . The rated power draws for the electrical appliances are shown in Table 2 . The percentages of convective heat gains [14] from different appliances, contributing to the net internal gain, are also indicated in the Table. Fig. 2 represents an estimated total daily electrical energy consumption used in the simulation. It includes the lighting, scheduled loads of the electrical appliances, the energy requirement for daily hot water usage, the heat recovery ventilator unit and the PV regulator - inverter unit. 3.1 Heating systems An air-to-air heat pump (HP) driven multi-split system 1 1 The TRNSYS heat pump outdoor and indoor-fan units (Type 221 and 222) are designed by Mr. Justin Tamasauskas as per the specifications given in Table 3 (Email: justin.tamasauskas@canada.ca) is used as the primary heating unit. The unit consists of an outdoor unit and three separate indoor fan units for the three zones. An electric baseboard (BB) heater is also available as a secondary heating unit for each zone. The HP heating performance depends on the outdoor temperature and may have lower coefficient of performance (COP) during the very cold days, hence for better reliability of the heating system the electric baseboards are used as the secondary units. The specifications are given in Table 3 . The required part-load ration (PLR) for each indoor fan unit of the multi-split system, given by P L R I N demand i , is optimized separately by the MPC. The total demanded heating capacity, Q H P demand is given by (1). (1) Q H P demand = ∑ i = 1 z ( P L R I N demand i × Q I N rated i ) where. Q H P demand Total HP heating capacity demand (kW). P L R I N demand i Indoor fan unit PLR for the i t h zone. Q I N rated i Rated heating capacity of the indoor fan unit for the i t h zone (kW). Z Total number of zones. Here, z = 3 . The PLR of the outdoor unit, however, is adjusted based on the Q H P demand and the available rated heating capacity of the outdoor unit, Q H P rated (kW). The Q H P rated and the electric power consumption, P H P rated (kW) of the outdoor unit are functions of the indoor and outdoor temperature as given in Ref. [21]. PLR, effective heating capacity and electric power consumption of the outdoor unit are given by the set of equations in (2).where. Q H P rated Rated heating capacity of the HP outdoor unit (kW). P H P rated Rated power consumption by the HP outdoor unit (kW). P L R O U Effective PLR for the HP outdoor unit. Q H P OU Effective heating capacity of the HP outdoor unit (kW). P H P OU Effective power consumption by the HP outdoor unit (kW). The relation between P L R O U and P H P OU is adopted from the articles [8,17]. The PLR of the indoor units are then adjusted by a heating capacity factor, F capacity , given by (3a). The effective PLR for the indoor units are given by P L R I N i in (3b), for each zone. (3a) F capacity = { 1 , Q H P demand < = Q H P rated Q H P rated Q H P demand , otherwise (3b) P L R I N i = P L R I N demand i × F capacity where. F capacity Heating capacity factor for the HP indoor units. P L R I N i Effective PLR for the indoor fan unit in the i t h zone. Equations (1)–(3) ensure that the total heating capacity of the individual fan units never exceeds the rated capacity of the outdoor unit of the multi-split system. The MPC only optimizes the P L R I N demand i as the control variable. P L R O U is a function of P L R I N demand i as given by eqs. (1) and (2a). The efficiency of the baseboards are assumed to be 100%. The heat pump driven multi-split systems have a lower installation cost and a faster response time. Since no thermal storage is considered here, when the heat pump is operating at a lower COP, the MPC utilizes the baseboards to provide the heating energy required to maintain the indoor operative temperature within the desired range. 3.2 PV panels (PV), home battery (HB) and grid (G): sizing and specifications The specifications for the PV panels, home battery and the bidirectional grid connection are discussed in the following. 3.2.1 Solar panels A simple glazed PV panel, (TRNSYS Type 562d module) is used to estimate the solar power generation using the solar radiation data given by the TMY2 weather file. The default specifications for the said PV module in TRNSYS remained unchanged, as shown in Table 4 , except the surface area. It is estimated to be 32.7 m 2 , assuming the average size of the PV system to be 6 kW [7]. The performance of the PV panel depends on the ambient conditions e.g., solar irradiance level, ambient temperature, wind speed, dirt/dust etc. [20] as well as the reference PV efficiency, the reference and actual temperatures the solar cell, total reference and actual incident solar radiation [32]. Since, an estimation of the generated power, based on a given weather condition, suffices the requirements of this particular study, a simplified model given by (4) is used for the simulation. (4) P P V = η P V × S I × A P V × ( τ α ) n × η R I where. P P V Total solar power generation (kW). S I Total solar irradiance (W/m2). A P V Total surface area of the PV panels (m2). η P V Efficiency of the PV panels. η R I Efficiency of the Regulator - Inverter unit. ( τ α ) n Transmittance - absorptance product of the PV cover for solar radiation at a normal angle. The efficiency of the regulator-inverter unit is set to 78%, equal to the default value of Type 48 module in TRNSYS [28]. The data for solar irradiance ( S I ) and the PV efficiency ( η P V ) are recorded from TRNSYS for the TMY2 - Toronto weather data. The normal solar transmittance ( τ n ) of the glass cover value is set to 0.86. Assuming the absorption factor, in Table 4, as the normal absorption factor ( α n ), the ( τ α ) n is approximated as ( τ α ) n = 1.01 × τ n × α n = 0.74 [6]. With this approximations of the PV panel parameter specifications, the power generation simulated by the model in (4) generates comparable results with respect to that of the Type 562d module in TRNSYS. It is worth mentioning that the simulation of the PV panels, is performed entirely within the MATLAB environment and the Type 562d for PV panels and Type 48 for the regulator-inverter module in TRNSYS are only used to derive the simplified model and its validation. 3.2.2 Home battery The specifications for the home battery is given in Table 5 . Except for the base case simulation scenario where for a rule based control strategy the minimum allowable state of charge (SOC) is restricted to 50%, in general, the SOC is allowed to vary between 10% and 90%. The SOC of the home battery is calculated in a discrete time frame at every simulation time step [19]. The update equations are given by eqs. (5) and (6).where. S O C B m a x Maximum allowable SOC for the home battery. 4 Control-oriented model identification and validation The control-oriented MATLAB models for the three zones, namely, the primary bedroom, secondary bedroom and the living-kitchen area (Fig. 1 ) are identified separately as linear time-invariant (LTI) state space sub-blocks as shown in Fig. 3 . System inputs: • External uncontrolled or disturbance inputs: – T e x t : Outdoor temperature ( ° C ). – q S G , z : Solar gain (kW) for z t h zone. – q I G , z : Internal thermal gains (kW) for z t h zone. – T g n d : Ground temperature ( ° C ). • Heating inputs: – q H P , z : Power inputs for the multi-split heat pump unit (kW) for z t h zone. – q B B , z : Power inputs for the baseboards (kW) for z t h zone. Open loop system identification is used to generate the simplified LTI house model. The MPC uses this control-oriented model to predict the system outputs during the heating season and accordingly optimizes the control inputs. Periodic pulse waves of 50% duty cycle, having amplitudes equal to the rated HP and BB heating capacity (Table 3) are supplied to respective zones for the system identification. System outputs: • T o p , z : Operative temperature ( ° C ) for z t h zone. • T a i r , z : Air temperature ( ° C ) for z t h zone. For system identification, the TMY2 Toronto weather data from January to the middle of March is used. The model validation is performed with the weather dataset for the same location, from the middle of March to the end of April. Distribution of the validation errors for the different zones vary within ± 2 ° C for close to 70% of the time. 5 Uncertainties in the disturbance inputs: weather inputs and internal gains The standard TRNSYS TMY2 dataset for Toronto is used as the actual or real-time data. The noise vectors are generated for every hour as recommended in Ref. [4] and linear interpolation is used between successive data points to generate a noise vector that matches the simulation time step of 3.75 min. These noise vectors are then added to the TMY2 dataset to generate the forecast data. 5.1 Forecast and actual dataset for outdoor temperature As suggested in Ref. [4], two vectors of normally distributed random variables are considered to be representing, respectively, the 6 h-ahead and the 1 h-ahead forecast noise for the outdoor temperature, T e x t . The mean and standard deviation of the prediction error considered for the 6 h-ahead forecast are 0.04 ° C and 2.2 ° C respectively. For the 1 h-ahead forecast, the prediction accuracy is assumed to be improved with a narrower standard deviation of 1.2 ° C . 5.2 Forecast and actual dataset for solar radiation on the PV and shortwave solar heat gain through windows 1 h, 6 h and 48 h-ahead forecasts for solar radiation are studied in Ref. [4] based on available weather dataset from Environment Canada. In the article, an estimated forecast error is defined by Gaussian noise with mean of 17 W/m2 and standard deviation of 167 W/m2 for the 6 h-ahead predictions. The 1 h-ahead prediction, is a Gaussian noise with the same mean but a smaller standard deviation of 100 W/m2. These are the prediction estimations for the solar radiation due 45 ° South and hence it is suitable for the solar radiation on the installed PV panels [4]. To generate the forecast error for the indoor solar heat gain due to the shortwave radiation through the windows, Gaussian noises with similar mean and standard deviation are used as the base for the 6 h and 1 h-ahead predictions. These base noise vectors are then weighted by the following three factors: Q s o l f a c t o r The relative solar heat gain factors [30], for the vertical façades at the different orientation of the building and at a different time of the day, with respect to South façade. A w Total window area (Table 1) on each façade corresponding to a zone (m2). G-value The solar energy transmittance of the windows. The G-value of the window glass is assumed to be 0.376. The Winter (corresponding to January 21 s t ) solar heat gain factors at 43 ° N latitude for Toronto, are considered as given in Ref. [30]. These factors are normalized with respect to the heat gain on the South façade and are listed in Table 6 . The Gaussian noise generated for the indoor solar heat gain on a given façade is given by the equation: (8) Q ¯ s o l n o i s e = Δ q ¯ S G × G − value × A w × Q s o l f a c t o r where. Δ q ¯ S G Base Gaussian noise vector for solar heat gain per unit area due South (W/m2). Q ¯ s o l n o i s e Net solar heat gain noise vector on a given façade (W). The solar heat gain noise, Q ¯ s o l n o i s e is generated separately for each façade of the house using (8), and then the total noise for each zone is added to the real-time data to generate the forecast to be used by the MPC. 5.3 Forecast and actual dataset for ground temperature and internal heat gain The variation in the ground surface temperature is ± 0.5 ° C [2]. Gaussian noise of 0 ° C mean and 0.17 ° C standard deviation is generated which gives the required range of prediction error for the ground temperature, T g n d . The internal heat gain is considered to be generated by the occupants, lights and electrical equipment. The schedules for occupancy and electricity usage for lights and appliances are pre-scheduled in the TRNSYS house. Hence, a Gaussian percentage deviation with zero mean and an approximate maximum deviation of ± 30 % is considered. 6 Problem formulation and methodology The goal here is to combine the control mechanism of two major building operations. The comfort goal focuses on meeting a predefined temperature range while reducing in the energy cost. Optimal usage of the heating units, thus, becomes an integral part of the comfort optimization. Judicious utilization of the energy efficient heat pump and benefiting from the off-peak ToU rates during the day by utilizing the energy storage unit, prove to be the two key factors implemented by the MPC for the comfort optimization [26,27]. The self-generated electricity from the roof-top PV panels can be used instantaneously to supply loads or can be stored in the home battery for future usage in a cost-effective way. The heating system is considered as a part of the house electricity load and thus the heating control system and the energy management system are intertwined to study a more centralized control scenario. The base case scenario includes an MPC controlled heating system and a rule based energy management system. 6.1 Comfort bounds and setpoint temperature The upper ( T u b ) and lower ( T l b ) acceptable temperature bounds and the setpoint trajectory ( T s e t ) are shown in Fig. 4 . In similar experiments presented in Ref. [26,27], it has been identified that, in absence of T s e t MPC is often prone to overheating while trying to achieve a suitable trade-off between cost and comfort, specially in the absence of forced cooling. To reduce this effect, the deviation of the operative temperature, T o p from T s e t is penalized in the objective function in addition to penalizing the deviation from the bounds. The temperature profile for T s e t is tunable and is chosen to maintain approximately the average of the upper and lower bounds and encourage a gradual transition from the night to the day-time comfort requirements. The penalty on comfort violation used in the MPC optimization is defined in eqs. (9) and (10). Two different non-negative tracking errors are taken into consideration. The e ¯ b o u n d i : R L × R L × R L → R L measures the deviation of T o p from the upper and lower temperature bounds (10). The e ¯ s e t i : R L × R L → R L in (9), on the other hand, is the absolute measure of the distance of T o p from T s e t . T ¯ s e t i Setpoint temperature ( ° C ) . 6.2 Simulation parameters A multistep MPC feedback strategy [12] is used here. Based on similar previous experiments conducted in Ref. [26,27], the simulation time step, prediction horizon (PH) and control horizon (CH) are chosen to be T s = 3.75 min, P H = 8 h and C H = 15 min, respectively. Since C H = 15 min, the first four optimized control values are implemented before the MPC performs the subsequent optimization. The MATLAB coded MPC uses a standard constrained optimization function fmincon from the MATLAB Optimization Toolbox. Particularly, the Active-Set algorithm is used here [18]. 6.2.1 Time-of-use (ToU) rates and feed-in-tariff (FiT) The Ontario ToU electricity rates [24], are used to estimate the energy cost as shown in Fig. 5 . The same rates are used as the Feed-in-Tariff (FiT) while considering an incentive for selling to the grid. As described in Ref. [16], currently, a flat average price reduction is implemented for different KWh slabs. Here, for the simulation purposes, the FiT is chosen identical to the ToU rates. 6.3 Description of the optimization variables The power flow equations, as functions of the optimization variables (Table 7 ), are given by the set of equations in (11). Here. z No. of zones in the house. L Length of P H . c ¯ b u y Time-of-Use rates (¢/kWh). c ¯ s e l l Feed-In Tariff (¢/kWh). w 1,2,3,4,5 Weights on the different penalty. Δ S O C B Change in the state of charge of the battery at each time step (kWh). The cost term, J cost gives the total energy cost corresponding to the net energy consumption from the grid over a given prediction horizon P H . The grid supplies the load demand from the house and charges the battery as needed. The timing and amount of power delivered from the grid is controlled by the MPC, by optimizing the variables F P V → H and F B → H as given in (11). The comfort term, J comfort in (12) includes the l 2 -norm of the deviation of T o p from the upper and lower temperature bounds and the absolute error of deviation from the setpoint as defined by eqs. (9) and (10). The weights on the cost and comfort terms ( w 1 , … , w 5 ), for respective zones, are used to scale the components of the objective function having different units and thus adjust the performance of the MPC controller. These weights are tunable parameters and the choices are based on user preference to achieve better trade-off between energy cost and comfort. Since this is a multivariable control optimization and a single objective function is used to optimize the MPC performance for the three zones simultaneously, the weights set priority on the goals to achieve the desired performance. The weights are specified as follows: w 1 Weight on c b u y . w 2 Weight on c s e l l . w 3 Weight on Δ S O C B . w 4 i Weights on the deviation from T b o u n d for i t h zone. w 5 i Weights on the deviation from T s e t for i t h zone. 7.1 Base case scenario An MPC controlled comfort management system is considered in the base case scenario along with a rule based energy management strategy described in the flowchart in Fig. 6 . The assumptions for the controller strategy for the base case scenario are as follows: • The power inputs to the heating units, i.e., P L R I N , F B B and P B , specifically the battery discharge power P B discharge only are controlled by the MPC. • The power consumptions by the HP and BB heating units are optimized based on the variable ToU rates. • A minimum 50% battery SOC is always maintained for emergency usage, i.e., S O C B m i n = 50 % . • Grid energy flow is bidirectional. Excess PV generated electricity can be fed back to the grid but without any incentive. The flowchart in Fig. 6 shows the energy flow diagram to and from PV, home battery, house and grid, for a single time step during the optimization in the base case scenario. The energy flow is primarily rule based. 7.1.1 Case I: bidirectional grid connection with an incentive for selling power to the grid This scenario considers bidirectional communication with the power grid. A two-way grid connection is available. A Feed-in-Tariff (FiT) same as the ToU rates (Section 6.2.1) is used. Same CH and PH are used here, as mentioned in 6.2. Based on similar experiments [26] the tunable weights defined in (12) are chosen as follows: w 1 = 1.5; w 2 = 1; w 3 = 5; w 4 1,2,3 = 3.2, same for all zones. w 5 1,2,3 = {0.08, 0.05, 0.08}, for the primary and secondary bedroom, and the living room respectively. 8 Results and discussion The performances of the MPC, for the above mentioned scenarios are analyzed for a 7-day simulation period. The simulation is run for 8 consecutive days during the first week of January and the first day is considered as a warm-up day. The TRNSYS-MATLAB co-simulation used for this study takes approximately 3 days in real-time to simulate 8 simulation days on an Intel Core-i7 processor with 8 GB RAM. Though computationally time-expensive, the controller is real-time implementable. But the extended simulation time restricts the choice of a longer simulation interval. In the following, the two case study scenarios are compared based on three performance criteria as discussed in the following. 8.1 Comfort performance Fig. 7 shows the operative temperature plots for the base case and Case I. Five consecutive days of simulation results are shown in the figure, as an example, for the primary bedroom (B1). The 1 h-ahead forecast and real-time outdoor temperature and respective solar heat gain for B1 are also indicated. The MPCs perform somewhat similarly, in maintaining the T o p within the specified limit, in both the cases. This is also reflected by the Time-in-Target performance in Fig. 8 , where the histogram of the deviations of T o p , in each case, is indicated for the entire 7-day simulation period. The temperature plot in Fig. 7, on the 4 t h day, shows a deviation of close to 2 ° C resulting from the significant dissimilarity in the forecast prediction for the solar heat gain. The MPC heats the zone considering a lower heat gain, which eventually results in overheating due to the solar radiation. Since no forced cooling is available, it takes a while before the T o p lower to reach the desired limit. Similarly, insufficient heating also results from over-prediction of the solar heat gain in the zone, as can be seen on the 2 n d or the 3 r d day. Here, the horizontal axis indicates the additional margin from either the upper or lower temperature bound defining the new target range. For example, the 0.5 ° C margin covers the range: T l b − 0.5 ≤ T o p ≤ T u b + 0.5 The Time-in-Target shown in Fig. 8, is based on the deviation from the upper and lower temperature bounds only. The e s e t defined in (9) with reference to the T s e t in Fig. 4, is used in the objective function to induce a penalty on the overheating effect, but no related penalty is considered in calculating the Time-in-Target performance. Above 85% of the time, the T o p in each zone, is maintained within a ± 0.5 ° C deviation margin, with a maximum deviation of close to ± 1 ° C . The secondary bedroom (B2), because of its North-East orientation (Fig. 1), has less solar heat gain than the primary bedroom (B1) and the living-kitchen (LK). Hence, the MPC maintains the T o p of zone B2, closer to the upper temperature bound in order to achieve a trade-off between the heating energy cost and the comfort performance. This leads to respectively 30% and 50% reduction in the Time-in-Target performance, as compared to the zones B1 and LK. However, the MPC performance in zone B2 matches with the other two zones while comparing with respect to the range of ± 0.5 ° C deviation margin. 8.2 Heating energy distribution The distribution of the heating energy between the HP and the BB heating units are also similar for the two scenarios. Fig. 9 shows a sample heating pattern in the Case I scenario for zone B1. The HP is used as the primary heating system since the average COP of the HP is 3.26 as compared to unity in case of the BB. HP preheats the zone to take advantage of the off-peak ToU rates, specially during the night. The HP net electricity consumptions are shown in Fig. 10 . Since 100% efficiency of the BB is assumed in general, the heat delivered by the BB is identical to its electricity consumption. The differences in the amounts of heating energy usage by the house in the two cases are minimal. The base case uses more BB heating. Based on the average heating energy delivered by the HP and BB, the average daily per unit cost of electricity for BB usage is approximately 20% more than that of HP usage for both the cases. 8.3 Use of renewable solar energy and battery storage unit The daily average energy flows from different sources to sinks are shown in Fig. 11 . Here, the labels on the horizontal axis are given by. E P V → H Energy delivered from PV to house (kWh). E P V → B Energy delivered from PV to home battery (kWh). E P V → G Energy delivered from PV to grid (kWh). E B → H Energy delivered from home battery to house (kWh). E B → G Energy delivered from home battery to grid (kWh). E G → H Energy delivered from grid to house (kWh). E G → B Energy delivered from grid to home battery (kWh). The rule based simulation scenario presented in the base case (Section 7.1), drives the PV generated energy to charge the battery in the morning as a priority. The battery is mostly used to deliver energy to the house at night and the MPC controls the amount of discharge. In comparison to the base case, the centralized MPC strategy in Case I, utilizes a larger share of the PV generated electricity to supply the instantaneous load demand of the house. E P V → H for the base is close to 66% less than Case I. Whereas, the rule based control in the base case utilizes the PV generated power mostly to charge the battery. The E P V → B in Case I is 78% less than the base case. The variation in S O C B is plotted in Fig. 12 . S O C B is maintained within 50%–90% for the base case. The battery charging is more flexible and may vary between 10% and 90% for Case I. 50% SOC level was considered as the initial condition at the first day of the 8-day simulation period, including the warm-up day. Here, the MPC charging strategy follows a general pattern of ‘two-phase’ charging. Initially, utilizing the off-peak prices at the start of the day, the battery is charged to supply the energy demand during the day-time on-peak period. In the second phase, the battery is charged using solar energy and supplies the demand during the second on-peak period in the evening. The first day, indicated in Fig. 12, is a weekend and the ToU rate off-peak throughout the day. As indicated in Fig. 7, the day is also cloudy. The MPC decides to minimally charge the battery to maintain the 10% SOC. Overall, to achieve the objective of minimizing the energy cost, the MPC tends to utilize approximately 10%–50% of the battery capacity and charges the battery only sufficiently to reduce the grid energy during the peak ToU periods. In general, the usage of grid energy is more in Case I, where the effect of the extra energy cost for buying energy from the grid is balanced by selling energy back to the grid. The average daily electricity costs are listed in Table 8 . The minimum is achieved in Case I, where a FiT is implemented for selling energy to the grid. In Case I, the simultaneous comfort and BEMS MPC optimization achieve a 13.5% reduction in the energy cost as compared to the base case. A simple case of MPC optimization for comfort management (without any BEMS control) is also simulated in TRNSYS as a reference to estimate the benefit of the centralized MPC controlled comfort and energy management system. Neither PV generation nor battery storage is considered in this case. The average daily cost achieved here is 3.16 C$, which is close to 31% more than Case I. 9 Conclusion In an effort to design a centralized system to control different components of the HVAC and BEMS systems simultaneously, a novel predictive control strategy is proposed in this article. By optimizing a single multi-objective cost function, the MPC maintains the operative temperature within a ± 0.5 ° C deviation margin from the predefined comfort bounds for over 85% of the simulation duration in each zone and achieves a 31% reduction in the daily average energy cost as compared to the grid-only building energy supply. The installation cost for the PV and the battery are not considered for these case studies. The multi-split air-to-air heat pump has a fast response time and maintains an average COP of 3.26 during the simulation period. Thus, the heat pump, along with the baseboard as a secondary heating unit builds an efficient and heating unit with low operative cost. The MPC controlled comfort and energy management system uses the PV generated solar energy to supply close to 10% of the total heating demand of the house, thereby saving approximately 198 gCO2 emission daily, considering 32 gCO2/kWh GHG emission factor for Ontario [15]. The reduction in the daily energy cost with respect to the grid based energy supply system indicates long term benefits in terms of cost minimization, leading to a cleaner environment. In this paper, the objective function optimizes energy cost and comfort. A modification in the objective function by incorporating a penalty on the GHG emission may achieve a further reduction in the CO2 emission. Specially in case of a mixed source energy generation scenario as in Ontario [10], a penalty on the GHG emission may play an effective contribution in achieving a reduction in the carbon footprint. However, for a greener grid scenario as in Quebec where more than 99% [11] of the total electricity generation is based on renewables, a cost-based objective function might be better appreciated. In summary, the MPC optimization method presented in this paper can be customized to incorporate various related control objectives to achieve user specific goals. coredata.dc:description: A novel implementation strategy of a centralized model predictive control (MPC) is proposed for a zone based comfort and energy management in a residential building. A photovoltaic (PV) solar system and a stationary home battery unit are considered. A heat pump (HP) is used as the primary heating unit. The electric baseboards (BB) are used as a supplementary system. The MPC controls the HP and BB power inputs for comfort management, as well as the energy flow among the PV, the battery and the bidirectional grid system. Variable Time-of-Use (ToU) rates are considered for the energy cost calculation and Feed-in-Tariff (FiT) is considered for selling energy to the grid. A 13.5% reduction in the energy cost is achieved with the centralized MPC as compared to a rule based energy management strategy. The solar energy generation and battery storage contribute to approximately 31% saving.
coredata.dc:title: Centralized model predictive control strategy for thermal comfort and residential energy management
